title: 107_hr1181
content: The "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001" is introduced, which includes a credit for health insurance costs of previously uninsured individuals under section 25B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001" introduces a tax credit for individuals who pay for qualified health insurance coverage for themselves, their spouse, and dependents. The credit is limited to $1,500 per eligible coverage month for up to two individuals. The tax credit introduced by the "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001" is limited to $1,500 per eligible coverage month for up to two individuals. Married individuals must file jointly to be eligible for the credit. An eligible coverage month is when an individual is covered by qualified health insurance paid for by the taxpayer. The tax credit under the "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001" is limited to $1,500 per eligible coverage month for individuals covered by qualified health insurance paid for by the taxpayer. An eligible coverage month is when the individual was not covered by qualified health insurance and not eligible for an employer-provided group health plan for a 12-month period. The credit amount allowed is reduced based on adjusted gross income. The tax credit amount allowed under the "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001" is reduced based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income. The reduction is calculated by a specific ratio of the taxpayer's income over the applicable dollar amount, not going below zero. The tax credit amount under the "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001" is based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income, which includes certain exclusions. The applicable dollar amount for the credit varies based on marital status and the number of individuals covered by the health insurance. Rounding rules apply to ensure accuracy in calculations. The tax credit amount under the "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001" is based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income, which includes certain exclusions. The credit amount varies based on marital status and the number of individuals covered by the health insurance. Qualified health insurance excludes coverage with less than 50% cost borne by the taxpayer. No credit is allowed for amounts paid under certain government-provided programs. The tax credit for qualified health insurance excludes coverage with less than 50% cost borne by the taxpayer. No credit is allowed for amounts paid under specific government-provided programs. The tax credit for qualified health insurance is subject to special rules, including coordination with other deductions and denial of credit to dependents. Dollar amounts for the credit are adjusted for inflation after 2002. Inflation adjustment for tax credit amounts after 2002, based on cost-of-living adjustment. Amounts rounded to nearest $100. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2001. Part VII of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section on costs of qualified health insurance. In general, individuals can deduct the amount paid for qualified health insurance coverage for themselves, their spouse, and dependents. Special rules apply, such as not double-counting the deduction with other medical deductions and not using it for self-employment tax purposes. Conforming amendments include adding a new item for the deduction in the Internal Revenue Code. The deduction for qualified health insurance costs is allowed for individuals, their spouse, and dependents. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include adding a new item for this deduction. The deduction for qualified health insurance costs is allowed for individuals, their spouse, and dependents, with amendments to the Internal Revenue Code. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2001.
